fields.headline: Doctors' costly contracts
fields.bodyText: I have two questions for the BMA (Europe's GPs fly in to cover unwanted shifts, June 17): where were they when the new contract, offering GPs a reduction of £6,000 per year for giving up all their out-of-hours work, was negotiated? Did they warn that this amount would be totally inadequate to provide a replacement service? Your report clearly says: "Most GPs ... saw they could do out-of-hours work ... and recoup their loss within seven or eight nights." No surprise there then. GPs deserve to be given the option of avoiding long hours, but the BMA should have clarified the replacement service with the NHS well before the change if they truly had the concern for patients that they are now displaying. Martin Cox Southampton If university professors in Germany were paid £250,000 a year, about five times the going rate here, where do I volunteer to provide weekend cover for my German counterparts? (Prof) Mike Heath Alton, Hants
